channel.title: NYT > World > Middle East

item.title: Gabriel Barkay, 81, Dies; His Discoveries Revised Biblical History
item.description: One of Israel’s leading archaeologists, he found evidence that the writing of the Old Testament likely began much earlier than historians had thought.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Gabriel Barkay in 2016, displaying a restored ancient tile excavated from the holy site in Jerusalem known to Jews as the Temple Mount. He earned a reputation as the “dean” of biblical archaeologists.

item.title: Syria’s President Affirms Kurds’ Rights, in Overture to the Minority
item.description: President Ahmed al-Sharaa’s announcement comes after days of deadly clashes between government and Kurdish forces that have underscored the difficulty he faces in uniting the country.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: People crossing a bridge as they flee from a Kurdish-controlled area, in Rasm al-Harmal, east of Aleppo, on Friday.

item.title: Iran Protests Quelled Since Deadly Crackdown, Residents Say
item.description: “There is massive disappointment and disillusionment,” one Tehran resident said. A human rights group acknowledged that demonstrations had been subdued since Sunday, with thousands of people detained.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Kiana Hayeri, Sanam Mahoozi and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A burned bus at Sadeghieh Square in Tehran on Thursday, after the protests were largely subdued.

item.title: Iran Has Had Protests Before. Will This Time Be Different?
item.description: Understanding the factors that can topple regimes.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Protesters in Tehran, Iran, last week.

item.title: Many Fiery Remarks, Little Clarity on What’s Next at Security Council Meeting on Iran
item.description: Iran’s representative denied the country had killed protesters, as the U.S. ambassador said President Trump had made clear “all options are on the table” to stop the killing.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ahmad Batebi, right, a human-rights activist, delivered remarks at the United Nations Security Council meeting on Iran on Thursday.

item.title: Israel and Arab Nations Ask Trump to Refrain From Attacking Iran
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel asked the president to postpone any planned attack. Israeli and Arab officials fear Iran could retaliate by striking their countries.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel with President Trump last month in Florida. The Israeli leader spoke to Mr. Trump on Wednesday, the same day that the president claimed Iran had stopped killing protesters.

item.title: Why Israel Is Wary of Intervening in Iran
item.description: Israel is unlikely to do much to try to precipitate a regime change in Iran, seeing the government as far from the brink of collapse and the current protests as insufficient to push it to that point.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger
item.media:description: A photograph posted on social media showing a protest in Tehran last week.

item.title: Iran Backpedals on Executions Threat but Casts Protesters as ‘Terrorists’
item.description: Iran’s judiciary said there was no death penalty issued for Erfan Soltani, whose case drew international outcry. Analysts say the government is using fear and intimidation to keep people off the streets.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Sanam Mahoozi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trump’s Gulf Allies Do Not Want Him to Bomb Iran
item.description: While several of the Gulf Arab countries harbor little love for Iran, they worry that the consequences of rising tensions could blow back on them.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A patriotic banner in Tehran on Wednesday.

item.title: What Are Trump’s Options in Iran?
item.description: President Trump has said that “help is on the way” for Iranian protesters. Amid reports that thousands of the protesters have been killed, our national security correspondent David E. Sanger describes what some of Mr. Trump’s options might be.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Coleman Lowndes, Nikolay Nikolov, Edward Vega, June Kim and Whitney Shefte

item.title: Iran Postpones Execution of Protester as Trump Threatens ‘Strong Action’
item.description: Iran had planned to put a 26-year-old protester to death amid the wave of unrest in the country, but apparently stood down for now.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir, Sanam Mahoozi and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A still from a video posted on social media of cars set on fire during a protest in Tehran last week.

item.title: An Emboldened Trump Makes Big Bets in Venezuela, Iran and Beyond
item.description: President Trump has left himself plenty of room for maximal intervention. But there are a host of potential wild cards, each with risks for the president.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Trump has left himself plenty of room for maximal intervention, in Tehran, Caracas and elsewhere.

item.title: Iran’s Leaders May Survive Protests. But Anger Will Likely Persist.
item.description: Its security forces have brutally defended the Islamic Republic, but the protests show that many Iranians consider it stagnant and ideologically hollow.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Some parts of Tehran saw heavy damage during protests in recent days.

item.title: Analysis: Trump Supports Protesters in Iran, but Not in Minneapolis
item.description: The split-screen television images of mass demonstrations in Minneapolis and Tehran have highlighted the president’s disparate views of democracy and popular dissent.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: The television images of mass protests in the streets of Minneapolis and Tehran in recent days have invariably highlighted the complications and contradictions of Donald J. Trump’s presidency.

item.title: U.S. to Name Palestinian Committee to Run Gaza
item.description: Officials said the body’s leadership could be announced as soon as Wednesday, but U.S. efforts to shape postwar Gaza by disarming Hamas have faced hurdles.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Saher Alghorra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gaza City on Tuesday. The territory faces major hurdles to rebuilding.

item.title: A Timeline of Protests in Iran
item.description: Amid a near-total communications blackout, witness footage trickling out of Iran paints a picture of how the country’s largest uprising in decades spread — and turned deadly.
item.dc:creator: Monika Cvorak and Sanjana Varghese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Trump Urges Antigovernment Protesters in Iran to ‘Take Over’
item.description: “HELP IS ON ITS WAY,” President Trump said on social media. He has threatened to intervene militarily on behalf of the protesters if Iran uses lethal force.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A burned-out building in Tehran on Saturday. Iran is experiencing the most expansive protests in years against its authoritarian rulers.

item.title: Trump Says He Will Impose Tariffs on Iran’s Trading Partners: What to Know
item.description: If President Trump follows through, some of Iran’s biggest trading partners, including China and India, could be hit hard.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump is exploring options for diplomacy with Iran as he weighs whether to attack the country to try to deter its leaders from killing more protesters, U.S. officials said.

item.title: As Iran’s Government Tries to Quell Protests, Accounts of Brutal Crackdown Emerge
item.description: As many as 3,000 feared dead as witnesses describe government forces firing on unarmed protesters.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Farnaz Fassihi, Sanam Mahoozi and Sanjana Varghese
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An image taken from social media and verified by The New York Times shows people looking for relatives as bodies piled up outside Tehran’s forensics laboratory on Sunday.

item.title: Reza Pahlavi, Son of Deposed Shah of Iran, Seeks Center Stage Amid Protests
item.description: Reza Pahlavi, living in exile in the United States, has long marketed himself as a future leader of Iran. His father’s repressive legacy casts a long shadow.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A demonstration in London on Sunday called on the British prime minister to support the Iranian people. Some Iranian protesters have rallied around Reza Pahlavi, the exiled son of the last shah of Iran.

item.title: How a Syrian Hiking Club Is Rediscovering the Country
item.description: The nearly 14-year civil war prevented Syrians from traveling freely to many parts of their own country. After the conflict ended a year ago, a group of outdoor enthusiasts began exploring newly accessible areas, fueled by a sense of adventure and hope.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim and Diego Ibarra Sanchez
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times

item.title: Trump Explores Diplomacy With Iran While Weighing Strikes, Officials Say
item.description: The Pentagon is presenting a wider range of strike options to the president than previously reported. Targets could include Iran’s nuclear program and ballistic missile sites.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Tyler Pager and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: An image taken from a social media post released on Friday showing demonstrators gathered in Tehran. President Trump has said that he would come to the aid of protesters if the Iranian government used lethal force against them.

item.title: Iran Says It Is Prepared for War but Ready to Negotiate After Trump’s Warnings
item.description: The comments came after President Trump said he was “ looking at some very strong options” to curb the Iranian authorities’ harsh repression of anti-government protests.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden and Sanam Mahoozi
item.media:description: Iran’s foreign minister, Abbas Araghchi, in Beirut, Lebanon, last week. On Monday, he expressed an openness to negotiations with the United States.

item.title: As Death Toll Surges in Iran, Leaders Take Tough Line Against Protesters
item.description: Despite an internet blackout, reports are emerging of a rise in deadly violence as protests spurred by economic woes have snowballed into a mass movement.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon and Sanam Mahoozi

item.title: Syrian Military Takes Aleppo Neighborhoods After Clashes With Kurds
item.description: The takeover ended one of the worst outbreaks of violence between the central government and the Kurdish-led forces since the end of the civil war just over a year ago.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Soldiers of the Syrian army in Aleppo on Saturday, following clashes between government forces and Kurdish fighters.

item.title: Israeli Police Question Top Netanyahu Aide Over Leaked Document Case
item.description: Tzachi Braverman, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s chief of staff, was detained for questioning on Sunday over accusations that he sought to impede an investigation.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Tzachi Braverman (standing), the chief of staff to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, was interviewed by the police on Sunday.

item.title: Death Toll Grows as Nationwide Protests Rock Iran for a Third Night
item.description: Antigovernment unrest that began two weeks ago has intensified in recent days, as has violence.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Malachy Browne
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: UGC, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A still from video shared on social media on Friday that has been verified by The New York Times showing crowds around an open fire in Tehran, Iran’s capital.
